avalancheActivity.comment: Due to snowfall and winds of different directions, new snow is distributed irregularly, so in places where a larger amount is piled up, it is possible to release an avalanche. Occasionally, smaller spontaneous avalanches from new snow are possible. More dangerous are generally places where there is older frozen snow under the new snow or in places with a smoother surface - grass or rock slabs.
avalancheActivity.highlights: Moderate avalanche danger in the high altitudes in Tatras and Low Tatras, 2nd degree

snowpackStructure.comment: During the snowfall, 10 to 30 cm of new snow fell on the mountains, with the least in the west and the most in the eastern and central mountains. During the night and the following day (22.11), a further 5 to 15 cm will fall. The snowfall is accompanied by fresh to strong winds with variable direction. Older, frozen snow can be found under the new snow from about 1800 m above sea level, especially on the northern slopes of the Tatra Mountains. At lower altitudes, the new snow fell mostly on grass or bedrock.

avalancheActivity.comment: The avalanche danger is local and is mainly related to locations with greater accumulation of new snow - steep couloirs and gullies. Smaller avalanches are possible here, especially with large additional loads.
avalancheActivity.highlights: In the Fatra Mountains, due to snowfall, a SMALL avalanche danger has been created, level 1.

snowpackStructure.comment: The heavier snowfall occurred mainly in the eastern half of Slovakia, with less, 10 to 25 cm of new snow in the Fatra Mountains. The new snow fell on a grassy base without old snow.

tendency.highlights: Persistent during the day, it should not snow heavily in this part of Slovakia today
